Award.AwardTitle: Boston University Noyce Urban Science Scholarships

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Boston University's Noyce Urban Science Scholarships (BoNUSS) program is providing 29 new scholarships to academically talented science majors. The departments within the College of Arts and Science, the School of Education and several local high-needs school districts (including Boston, Chelsea, Everett, Malden, Quincy Revere and Somerville) are partnering to provide scholarships for 24 recent graduates with science degrees to return to BU and undertake the Master of Arts in Teaching (MAT). In addition, 5 new undergraduate scholars are being funded to complete their licensure program in one year and teach in surrounding high-needs districts. The program follows the previously established model at BU shown to be successful with students majoring in mathematics. Pre-service teachers are exposed to a curriculum enriched with information and guest lecturers that address challenges faced by in-service teachers serving in urban settings. In addition, following their practicum year, project personnel are offering continuing support for the new teachers including access to a Master Teacher who offers monthly seminars intended to address issues of classroom management, and conducts regular online sessions to provide support, advice, mentoring and help with curricular challenges encountered by new teachers. The evaluation of the Noyce BoNUSS program also is identifying strategies that lead to the creation of an effective science preparation program to attract, prepare and retain high-quality secondary STEM teachers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

The Boston University Noyce Urban Science Scholarship (BoNUSS) Program had as its principal objective increasing the number of science majors (baccalaureate and post-baccalaureate) who earned a teaching license and went on to teach in high need school districts. Over the course of our National Science Foundation Robert Noyce Scholarship grant, from September, 2013 through August, 2019, Project BoNUSS prepared thirty-one science teachers who subsequently taught for at least two years in a high need school district. Of those who earned their teaching license with the support of Project BoNUSS, 8 became biology teachers, 4 became chemistry teachers, 5 became middle school general science teachers, and 14 became physics teachers. The scholarship that was provided was funded both by our NSF grant, and with additional scholarship money from Boston University to support this effort.

The broad impact of our project can be measured by the number of science teachers prepared by Project BoNUSS to teach in high need districts. While the total number of teachers we prepared may be small relative to national needs, each of these teachers can be expected to affect the learning of up to 5000 students over the course of their career. The need for chemistry and physics teachers is especially great. Nationally, the number of chemistry and physics teachers with a major in their content field hovers around 40%. For this reason, even a small addition to the number of chemistry and physics teachers who are teaching in high need districts may be significant in the long run.

The intellectual merit of Project BoNUSS is in the change in the courses that Boston University offers new science teachers seeking licensure, something documented and presented at the Noyce Summit in 2019. Specifically, from the feedback received from the Scholars during their licensure program and their first years of teaching, we developed an approach to preparing new science teachers for culturally responsive teaching in school districts where the majority of students come from homes of low socioeconomic status. The course designed for this purpose combines the initial experience of pre-service teachers in the school where they will be a student-teacher with assignments to investigate the community served by the school and develop lesson plans suited to the community. The integration of such explicit community research into licensure courses is expected to provide new teachers with the knowledge of how to better integrate their teaching with the life experiences of their students.
